title: Authors and Citation
text: Naeem Khoshnevis. Author, maintainer.            FASRC Boyu Ren. Author.            McLean Hospital Tanujt Dey. Author.            HMS Danielle Braun. Author.            HSPH

title: Authors and Citation
text: Khoshnevis N, Ren B, Dey T, Braun D (2022). GPCERF: Package (One Line, Title Case). R package version 0.0.1, https://github.com/fasrc/GPCERF.
code: @Manual{,   title = {GPCERF: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)},   author = {Naeem Khoshnevis and Boyu Ren and Tanujt Dey and Danielle Braun},   year = {2022},   note = {R package version 0.0.1},   url = {https://github.com/fasrc/GPCERF}, }

title: Gaussian Process (GP) approach for nonparametric modeling.
text: Gaussian Process (GP) approach nonparametric modeling.

title: Gaussian Process (GP) approach for nonparametric modeling.
code: library("devtools") install_github("fasrc/GPCERF", ref="develop") library("GPCERF")

title: Gaussian Process (GP) approach for nonparametric modeling.
code: sim.data <- generate_synthetic_data(sample_size = 500, gps_spec = 3)    # Estimate GPS function   # In the future, CausalGPS gps estimation will be used.   GPS_m <- train_GPS(cov.mt = as.matrix(sim.data[,-(1:2)]),                      w.all = as.matrix(sim.data$treat))    # exposure values   w.all = seq(0,20,0.1)    data.table::setDT(sim.data)    cerf_gp_obj <- estimate_cerf_gp(sim.data,                                   w.all,                                   GPS_m,                                   params = list(alpha = c(0.1,0.2,0.4),                                                 beta=0.2,                                                 g_sigma = 1,                                                 tune_app = "all"))

title: Gaussian Process (GP) approach for nonparametric modeling.
text: Ren, B., Wu, X., Braun, D., Pillai, N. Dominici, F., 2021. Bayesian modeling exposure response curve via gaussian processes: Causal effects exposure air pollution health outcomes. arXiv preprint arXiv:2105.03454.

title: The 'GPCERF' package. — GPCERF-package
text: Naeem Khoshnevis Boyu Ren Tanujit Dey Danielle Braun

title: Calculate Covariate Balance — calc_ac
text: Calculate weighted correlation list covariates exposure. Weights defined covariance function GP.

title: Calculate Covariate Balance — calc_ac
code: calc_ac(w, X, weights)

title: Calculate Covariate Balance — calc_ac
text: w vector exposure values across subjects. X matrix covariate values. Subjects rows covariates columns. weights vector weights assigned subjects based trained GP.

title: Calculate Covariate Balance — calc_ac
text: vector correlations w column X.

title: Calculate Covariate Balance — calc_ac
code: set.seed(429)  # generate data data <- generate_synthetic_data(sample_size = 200, gps_spec = 3)  # generate random weights weights <- runif(nrow(data)) weights <- weights/sum(weights)  # covariate matrix design_mt <- model.matrix(~.-1, data = data[, 3:ncol(data)])  cb <- calc_ac(w = data$treat, X = design_mt, weights=weights)

what: Compute Matrix Inverse For a Covariate Matrix — compute_inverse
title: Compute Matrix Inverse For a Covariate Matrix — compute_inverse
text: Computes inverse covariate matrix using Choleski decomposition.

title: Compute Matrix Inverse For a Covariate Matrix — compute_inverse
code: compute_inverse(mtrx)

title: Compute Matrix Inverse For a Covariate Matrix — compute_inverse
text: mtrx n*n covariate matrix

title: Compute Matrix Inverse For a Covariate Matrix — compute_inverse
text: Inverse matrix

title: Compute Matrix Inverse For a Covariate Matrix — compute_inverse
code: set.seed(934) A <- runif(10) B <- runif(10) C = cbind(A, B) kernel_fn = function(x) exp(-x^2) D = kernel_fn(as.matrix(dist(C))) inv_sigma_obs <- compute_inverse(D)

what:
Compute mean, confidence interval (?), and covariate balance in Full Gaussian
Process (GP) — compute_m_sigma
title:
Compute mean, confidence interval (?), and covariate balance in Full Gaussian
Process (GP) — compute_m_sigma
text: Calculates induced covariate balance associated one hyper-parameter configuration full GP.

title:
Compute mean, confidence interval (?), and covariate balance in Full Gaussian
Process (GP) — compute_m_sigma
code: compute_m_sigma(hyperparam, data, w, GPS_m, kernel_fn = function(x) exp(-x^2))

title:
Compute mean, confidence interval (?), and covariate balance in Full Gaussian
Process (GP) — compute_m_sigma
text: hyperparam vector values hyper-parameters. First element: alpha Second element: beta Third element: g_sigma (gamma/sigma) data  data.table containing data including outcome, exposure covariates. following order: Column 1: Outcome (Y) Column 2: Exposure treatment (w) Column 3~m: Confounders (C) w vector exposure levels CERF estimated. GPS_m data.table GPS vectors. Column 1: vector estimated GPS evaluated observed exposure levels. Column 2: Estimated conditional means exposure given covariates samples (e_gps_pred). Column 3: Estimated conditional standard deviation exposure given covariates samples (e_gps_std). kernel_fn covariance function GP.

title:
Compute mean, confidence interval (?), and covariate balance in Full Gaussian
Process (GP) — compute_m_sigma
text: list containing two elements: 1) vector absolute weighted correlation covariate exposure, metric covariate balance 2) estimated CERF w.based hyper-parameter values param.

title:
Compute mean, confidence interval (?), and covariate balance in Full Gaussian
Process (GP) — compute_m_sigma
code: set.seed(912) data <- generate_synthetic_data(sample_size = 250, gps_spec = 3)  w.all = seq(0,20,0.1)  data.table::setDT(data)  #Estimate GPS function GPS_m <- train_GPS(cov.mt = as.matrix(data[,-(1:2)]),                    w.all = as.matrix(data$treat)) #> [1]	train-rmse:8.427889  #> [2]	train-rmse:6.576370  #> [3]	train-rmse:5.230828  #> [4]	train-rmse:4.278385  #> [5]	train-rmse:3.617112  #> [6]	train-rmse:3.117391  #> [7]	train-rmse:2.677701  #> [8]	train-rmse:2.408476  #> [9]	train-rmse:2.268592  #> [10]	train-rmse:2.135648  #> [11]	train-rmse:1.998507  #> [12]	train-rmse:1.922534  #> [13]	train-rmse:1.871516  #> [14]	train-rmse:1.679066  #> [15]	train-rmse:1.484187  #> [16]	train-rmse:1.383167  #> [17]	train-rmse:1.327371  #> [18]	train-rmse:1.265584  #> [19]	train-rmse:1.182439  #> [20]	train-rmse:1.116496  #> [21]	train-rmse:1.098770  #> [22]	train-rmse:1.075959  #> [23]	train-rmse:0.971201  #> [24]	train-rmse:0.909766  #> [25]	train-rmse:0.853721  #> [26]	train-rmse:0.785449  #> [27]	train-rmse:0.720735  #> [28]	train-rmse:0.671513  #> [29]	train-rmse:0.634115  #> [30]	train-rmse:0.619789  #> [31]	train-rmse:0.587799  #> [32]	train-rmse:0.555885  #> [33]	train-rmse:0.509312  #> [34]	train-rmse:0.492669  #> [35]	train-rmse:0.476967  #> [36]	train-rmse:0.458201  #> [37]	train-rmse:0.422026  #> [38]	train-rmse:0.397187  #> [39]	train-rmse:0.372963  #> [40]	train-rmse:0.340009  #> [41]	train-rmse:0.318250  #> [42]	train-rmse:0.298455  #> [43]	train-rmse:0.283954  #> [44]	train-rmse:0.263343  #> [45]	train-rmse:0.237295  #> [46]	train-rmse:0.211401  #> [47]	train-rmse:0.197621  #> [48]	train-rmse:0.187469  #> [49]	train-rmse:0.175141  #> [50]	train-rmse:0.169089   tune_res <- compute_m_sigma(hyperparam = c(0.09, 0.09, 10),                             data = data,                             w = w.all,                             GPS_m = GPS_m)  gp.cerf <- tune_res$est

what: Calculate Posterior Means for nnGP Model — compute_posterior_m_nn
title: Calculate Posterior Means for nnGP Model — compute_posterior_m_nn
text: Calculate posterior mean point CERF based nnGP model. function also returns weights assigned nearest neighbors calculating posterior mean.

title: Calculate Posterior Means for nnGP Model — compute_posterior_m_nn
code: compute_posterior_m_nn(   hyperparam,   w,   GPS_w,   obs_ord,   y_obs_ord,   n_neighbor = 10,   expand = 5,   block_size = 10000 )

title: Calculate Posterior Means for nnGP Model — compute_posterior_m_nn
text: hyperparam set hyperparameters GP model. w scaler representing exposure level point interest CERF. GPS_w GPS samples exposure levels set w. obs_ord matrix two columns. First column observed exposure levels samples; second GPS observed exposure levels. rows ascending order first column. y_obs_ord vector observed outcome values. vector ordered obs_ord. n_neighbor Number nearest neighbors one side (see also expand). expand Scaling factor determine total number nearest neighbors. total 2*expand*n_neighbor. block_size Number samples included computation block. Mainly used balance speed memory requirement. Larger block_size faster, requires memory.

title: Calculate Posterior Means for nnGP Model — compute_posterior_m_nn
text: two column matrix. first column weights assigned nearest neighbor. second column corresponding observed outcome value. weight last row matrix NA observed outcome value estimated posterior mean CERF point w, weighted sum observed outcome values neighbors.

title: Calculate Posterior Means for nnGP Model — compute_posterior_m_nn
code: set.seed(1029) data <- generate_synthetic_data(sample_size = 200, gps_spec = 3)  # Estimate GPS function GPS_m <- train_GPS(cov.mt = as.matrix(data[,-(1:2)]),                    w.all = as.matrix(data$treat)) #> [1]	train-rmse:8.638411  #> [2]	train-rmse:6.684169  #> [3]	train-rmse:5.280511  #> [4]	train-rmse:4.210358  #> [5]	train-rmse:3.445020  #> [6]	train-rmse:2.926105  #> [7]	train-rmse:2.576079  #> [8]	train-rmse:2.226426  #> [9]	train-rmse:2.039993  #> [10]	train-rmse:1.877985  #> [11]	train-rmse:1.672212  #> [12]	train-rmse:1.534243  #> [13]	train-rmse:1.395933  #> [14]	train-rmse:1.343686  #> [15]	train-rmse:1.265116  #> [16]	train-rmse:1.157620  #> [17]	train-rmse:1.082999  #> [18]	train-rmse:1.005585  #> [19]	train-rmse:0.953592  #> [20]	train-rmse:0.916113  #> [21]	train-rmse:0.849501  #> [22]	train-rmse:0.805278  #> [23]	train-rmse:0.713429  #> [24]	train-rmse:0.650030  #> [25]	train-rmse:0.606354  #> [26]	train-rmse:0.576898  #> [27]	train-rmse:0.516545  #> [28]	train-rmse:0.500094  #> [29]	train-rmse:0.478638  #> [30]	train-rmse:0.460735  #> [31]	train-rmse:0.424055  #> [32]	train-rmse:0.390093  #> [33]	train-rmse:0.375137  #> [34]	train-rmse:0.351361  #> [35]	train-rmse:0.334023  #> [36]	train-rmse:0.326562  #> [37]	train-rmse:0.292652  #> [38]	train-rmse:0.261142  #> [39]	train-rmse:0.252173  #> [40]	train-rmse:0.246557  #> [41]	train-rmse:0.226317  #> [42]	train-rmse:0.203499  #> [43]	train-rmse:0.190649  #> [44]	train-rmse:0.173254  #> [45]	train-rmse:0.160964  #> [46]	train-rmse:0.154453  #> [47]	train-rmse:0.140818  #> [48]	train-rmse:0.136060  #> [49]	train-rmse:0.125336  #> [50]	train-rmse:0.117633   # Hyperparameter hyperparam <- c(0.1, 0.2, 1) n_neighbor <- 10 expand <- 1 block_size <- 10000  # Exposure level wi <- 0.4  # Estimate GPS for the exposure level GPS_w <- dnorm(wi,                mean = GPS_m$e_gps_pred,                sd = GPS_m$e_gps_std, log = TRUE)  # Order data for easy selection coord_obs = cbind(data$treat, GPS_m$GPS) y_use <- data$Y  obs_ord <- coord_obs[order(coord_obs[,1]),] y_use_ord <- y_use[order(coord_obs[,1])]  val <- compute_posterior_m_nn(hyperparam = hyperparam,                               w = wi,                               GPS_w = GPS_w,                               obs_ord = obs_ord,                               y_obs_ord = y_use_ord,                               n_neighbor = n_neighbor,                               expand = expand,                               block_size = block_size)

what: Calculate Posterior Standard Deviations for nnGP Model — compute_posterior_sd_nn
title: Calculate Posterior Standard Deviations for nnGP Model — compute_posterior_sd_nn
text: Calculates posterior standard deviation point CERF based nnGP model.

title: Calculate Posterior Standard Deviations for nnGP Model — compute_posterior_sd_nn
code: compute_posterior_sd_nn(   hyperparam,   w,   GPS_w,   obs_ord,   sigma2,   n_neighbor = 10,   expand = 1 )

title: Calculate Posterior Standard Deviations for nnGP Model — compute_posterior_sd_nn
text: hyperparam Values hyperparameters GP model. w exposure level point interest CERF. GPS_w GPS samples exposure levels set w. obs_ord matrix two columns. First column observed exposure levels samples; second GPS observed exposure levels. rows ascending order first column. sigma2 scaler representing sigma^2 n_neighbor Number nearest neighbours one side (see also expand). expand Scaling factor determine total number nearest neighbours. total 2*expand*n_neighbor.

title: Calculate Posterior Standard Deviations for nnGP Model — compute_posterior_sd_nn
text: posterior standard deviation estimated CERF w.

title: Calculate Posterior Standard Deviations for nnGP Model — compute_posterior_sd_nn
code: set.seed(3089) data <- generate_synthetic_data(sample_size = 200, gps_spec = 3)  # Estimate GPS function GPS_m <- train_GPS(cov.mt = as.matrix(data[,-(1:2)]),                    w.all = as.matrix(data$treat)) #> [1]	train-rmse:7.977744  #> [2]	train-rmse:6.473513  #> [3]	train-rmse:5.278797  #> [4]	train-rmse:4.420680  #> [5]	train-rmse:3.853461  #> [6]	train-rmse:3.509004  #> [7]	train-rmse:3.157153  #> [8]	train-rmse:2.889879  #> [9]	train-rmse:2.738637  #> [10]	train-rmse:2.645362  #> [11]	train-rmse:2.533985  #> [12]	train-rmse:2.409443  #> [13]	train-rmse:2.083127  #> [14]	train-rmse:1.919730  #> [15]	train-rmse:1.793337  #> [16]	train-rmse:1.656956  #> [17]	train-rmse:1.432716  #> [18]	train-rmse:1.390796  #> [19]	train-rmse:1.330662  #> [20]	train-rmse:1.205500  #> [21]	train-rmse:1.067686  #> [22]	train-rmse:0.967307  #> [23]	train-rmse:0.860374  #> [24]	train-rmse:0.783083  #> [25]	train-rmse:0.744678  #> [26]	train-rmse:0.691237  #> [27]	train-rmse:0.636118  #> [28]	train-rmse:0.605575  #> [29]	train-rmse:0.563186  #> [30]	train-rmse:0.543300  #> [31]	train-rmse:0.527330  #> [32]	train-rmse:0.473954  #> [33]	train-rmse:0.437780  #> [34]	train-rmse:0.403503  #> [35]	train-rmse:0.358255  #> [36]	train-rmse:0.328236  #> [37]	train-rmse:0.306226  #> [38]	train-rmse:0.281044  #> [39]	train-rmse:0.270485  #> [40]	train-rmse:0.263219  #> [41]	train-rmse:0.221316  #> [42]	train-rmse:0.203244  #> [43]	train-rmse:0.197485  #> [44]	train-rmse:0.180673  #> [45]	train-rmse:0.169092  #> [46]	train-rmse:0.151325  #> [47]	train-rmse:0.138258  #> [48]	train-rmse:0.124188  #> [49]	train-rmse:0.111664  #> [50]	train-rmse:0.104917   # Hyperparameter hyperparam <- c(0.1, 0.2, 1) n_neighbor <- 10 expand <- 1 block_size <- 10000  # Exposure level wi <- 0.4  # Estimate GPS for the exposure level GPS_w = dnorm(wi,               mean = GPS_m$e_gps_pred,               sd = GPS_m$e_gps_std, log = TRUE)  # Order data for easy selection coord_obs = cbind(data$treat, GPS_m$GPS) y_use <- data$Y  obs_ord <- coord_obs[order(coord_obs[,1]),] y_use_ord <- y_use[order(coord_obs[,1])]  # compute noise noise <- estimate_noise_nn(hyperparam = hyperparam,                            w_obs = data$treat,                            GPS_obs = GPS_m$GPS,                            y_obs = y_use_ord,                            n_neighbor = n_neighbor)  # compute posterior standard deviation pst_sd <- compute_posterior_sd_nn(hyperparam = hyperparam,                                   w = wi,                                   GPS_w = GPS_w,                                   obs_ord = obs_ord,                                   sigma2 = noise,                                   n_neighbor = 20,                                   expand = 1)

title: Compute Posterior Credible Interval — compute_sd_gp
text: Computes posterior credible interval requested exposure level

title: Compute Posterior Credible Interval — compute_sd_gp
code: compute_sd_gp(   w,   scaled_obs,   hyperparam,   sigma,   GPS_m,   kernel_fn = function(x) exp(-x^2) )

title: Compute Posterior Credible Interval — compute_sd_gp
text: w scalar exposure level interest. scaled_obs matrix two columns. First column scaled GPS value samples (GPS * 1/sqrt(alpha)) Second column scaled exposure value samples (w * 1/sqrt(beta)) hyperparam vector hyper-parameters GP. First element: alpha Second element: beta Third element: gamma/sigma sigma scaler represents noise. GPS_m data.table GPS vectors. Column 1: vector estimated GPS evaluated observed exposure levels. Column 2: Estimated conditional means exposure given covariates samples (e_gps_pred). Column 3: Estimated conditional standard deviation exposure given covariates samples (e_gps_std). kernel_fn covariance function GP.

title: Compute Posterior Credible Interval — compute_sd_gp
text: Posterior credible interval (scaler) requested exposure level (w).

title: Compute Posterior Credible Interval — compute_sd_gp
code: set.seed(284) #Generate synthetic data data <- generate_synthetic_data(sample_size = 200, gps_spec = 3) w_obs <- obs_exposure <- data$treat  # Choose an exposure level to compute CERF w = 1.2  # Define kernel function kernel_fn <- function(x) exp(-x^2)  # Estimate GPS function GPS_m <- train_GPS(cov.mt = as.matrix(data[,-(1:2)]),                    w.all = as.matrix(data$treat)) #> [1]	train-rmse:8.126090  #> [2]	train-rmse:6.346745  #> [3]	train-rmse:5.160632  #> [4]	train-rmse:4.237126  #> [5]	train-rmse:3.639487  #> [6]	train-rmse:3.173138  #> [7]	train-rmse:2.860692  #> [8]	train-rmse:2.588496  #> [9]	train-rmse:2.294354  #> [10]	train-rmse:2.076848  #> [11]	train-rmse:1.911738  #> [12]	train-rmse:1.698649  #> [13]	train-rmse:1.627178  #> [14]	train-rmse:1.490352  #> [15]	train-rmse:1.341344  #> [16]	train-rmse:1.225390  #> [17]	train-rmse:1.130175  #> [18]	train-rmse:1.009345  #> [19]	train-rmse:0.955622  #> [20]	train-rmse:0.892145  #> [21]	train-rmse:0.820646  #> [22]	train-rmse:0.780097  #> [23]	train-rmse:0.762133  #> [24]	train-rmse:0.717963  #> [25]	train-rmse:0.659093  #> [26]	train-rmse:0.589844  #> [27]	train-rmse:0.579641  #> [28]	train-rmse:0.523528  #> [29]	train-rmse:0.491045  #> [30]	train-rmse:0.466017  #> [31]	train-rmse:0.403185  #> [32]	train-rmse:0.350622  #> [33]	train-rmse:0.312244  #> [34]	train-rmse:0.282975  #> [35]	train-rmse:0.247362  #> [36]	train-rmse:0.223535  #> [37]	train-rmse:0.205091  #> [38]	train-rmse:0.197085  #> [39]	train-rmse:0.183195  #> [40]	train-rmse:0.166145  #> [41]	train-rmse:0.160136  #> [42]	train-rmse:0.151294  #> [43]	train-rmse:0.136097  #> [44]	train-rmse:0.128665  #> [45]	train-rmse:0.116861  #> [46]	train-rmse:0.113192  #> [47]	train-rmse:0.107310  #> [48]	train-rmse:0.101266  #> [49]	train-rmse:0.096414  #> [50]	train-rmse:0.085752   GPS <- GPS_m$GPS  # set hyperparameters hyperparam <- c(0.1, 0.4, 1) alpha <- hyperparam[[1]] beta <- hyperparam[[2]] g_sigma <- hyperparam[[3]]  # Compute scaled observation data and inverse of covariate matrix. scaled_obs <- cbind(obs_exposure*sqrt(1/alpha), GPS*sqrt(1/beta))  tentative_sigma <- 0.1  post_sd <- GPCERF:::compute_sd_gp(w = w,                                  scaled_obs = scaled_obs,                                  hyperparam = hyperparam,                                  sigma = tentative_sigma,                                  GPS_m = GPS_m,                                  kernel_fn = kernel_fn)

code: set.seed(124) mydata <- generate_synthetic_data(sample_size = 200) data.table::setDT(mydata) weights <- runif(nrow(mydata)) compute_w_corr(mydata, weights) #> [1] 0.016719786 0.011258911 0.025201922 0.009762202 0.001935777 0.011162120

what: Calculate Weights for Estimation of a Point on CERF — compute_weight_gp
title: Calculate Weights for Estimation of a Point on CERF — compute_weight_gp
text: Calculates weights observed outcomes used estimate posterior mean CERF given exposure level.

title: Calculate Weights for Estimation of a Point on CERF — compute_weight_gp
code: compute_weight_gp(   w,   w_obs,   scaled_obs,   hyperparam,   inv_sigma_obs,   GPS_m,   kernel_fn = function(x) exp(-x^2) )

title: Calculate Weights for Estimation of a Point on CERF — compute_weight_gp
text: w scalar exposure level interest. w_obs vector observed exposure levels samples. scaled_obs matrix two columns. First column scaled GPS value samples (GPS * 1/sqrt(alpha)) Second column scaled exposure value samples (w * 1/sqrt(beta)) hyperparam vector hyper-parameters GP. First element: alpha Second element: beta Third element: gamma/sigma inv_sigma_obs Inverse covariance matrix observed samples. GPS_m data.table GPS vectors. Column 1: vector estimated GPS evaluated observed exposure levels. Column 2: Estimated conditional means exposure given covariates samples (e_gps_pred). Column 3: Estimated conditional standard deviation exposure given covariates samples (e_gps_std). kernel_fn covariance function GP.

title: Calculate Weights for Estimation of a Point on CERF — compute_weight_gp
text: vector weights assigned sample calculate posterior mean CERF w.

title: Calculate Weights for Estimation of a Point on CERF — compute_weight_gp
code: set.seed(814) #Generate synthetic data data <- generate_synthetic_data(sample_size = 200, gps_spec = 3) w_obs <- obs_exposure <- data$treat  # Choose an exposure level to compute CERF w = 1.8  # Define kernel function kernel_fn <- function(x) exp(-x^2)  # Estimate GPS function GPS_m <- train_GPS(cov.mt = as.matrix(data[,-(1:2)]),                    w.all = as.matrix(data$treat)) #> [1]	train-rmse:8.518013  #> [2]	train-rmse:6.599013  #> [3]	train-rmse:5.244557  #> [4]	train-rmse:4.278952  #> [5]	train-rmse:3.581683  #> [6]	train-rmse:3.110262  #> [7]	train-rmse:2.729777  #> [8]	train-rmse:2.372004  #> [9]	train-rmse:2.168685  #> [10]	train-rmse:1.997748  #> [11]	train-rmse:1.872003  #> [12]	train-rmse:1.710224  #> [13]	train-rmse:1.615765  #> [14]	train-rmse:1.505119  #> [15]	train-rmse:1.443780  #> [16]	train-rmse:1.307533  #> [17]	train-rmse:1.206575  #> [18]	train-rmse:1.084150  #> [19]	train-rmse:0.987164  #> [20]	train-rmse:0.942421  #> [21]	train-rmse:0.838929  #> [22]	train-rmse:0.820173  #> [23]	train-rmse:0.770308  #> [24]	train-rmse:0.689476  #> [25]	train-rmse:0.651063  #> [26]	train-rmse:0.633587  #> [27]	train-rmse:0.600223  #> [28]	train-rmse:0.572636  #> [29]	train-rmse:0.500716  #> [30]	train-rmse:0.464365  #> [31]	train-rmse:0.452429  #> [32]	train-rmse:0.429480  #> [33]	train-rmse:0.398041  #> [34]	train-rmse:0.375698  #> [35]	train-rmse:0.355093  #> [36]	train-rmse:0.323831  #> [37]	train-rmse:0.305062  #> [38]	train-rmse:0.266530  #> [39]	train-rmse:0.228876  #> [40]	train-rmse:0.221280  #> [41]	train-rmse:0.208385  #> [42]	train-rmse:0.186859  #> [43]	train-rmse:0.177080  #> [44]	train-rmse:0.165706  #> [45]	train-rmse:0.155867  #> [46]	train-rmse:0.149401  #> [47]	train-rmse:0.139728  #> [48]	train-rmse:0.132120  #> [49]	train-rmse:0.121464  #> [50]	train-rmse:0.108209   GPS <- GPS_m$GPS  # set hyperparameters hyperparam <- c(0.1, 0.4, 1) alpha <- hyperparam[1] beta <- hyperparam[2] g_sigma <- hyperparam[3]  # Compute scaled observation data and inverse of covariate matrix. scaled_obs <- cbind(obs_exposure*sqrt(1/alpha), GPS*sqrt(1/beta)) sigma_obs <- g_sigma*kernel_fn(as.matrix(dist(scaled_obs))) + diag(nrow(scaled_obs)) inv_sigma_obs <- compute_inverse(sigma_obs)   weight <- compute_weight_gp(w = w,                             w_obs = w_obs,                             scaled_obs = scaled_obs,                             hyperparam = hyperparam,                             inv_sigma_obs = inv_sigma_obs,                             GPS_m = GPS_m,                             kernel_fn = kernel_fn)

what: Estimate the Conditional Exposure Response Function using Gaussian Process — estimate_cerf_gp
title: Estimate the Conditional Exposure Response Function using Gaussian Process — estimate_cerf_gp
text: Estimates conditional exposure response function (cerf) using Gaussian Process (gp). function tune best match (lowest covariate balance) provided set hyperparameters.

title: Estimate the Conditional Exposure Response Function using Gaussian Process — estimate_cerf_gp
code: estimate_cerf_gp(data, w, GPS_m, params, kernel_fn = function(x) exp(-x^2))

title: Estimate the Conditional Exposure Response Function using Gaussian Process — estimate_cerf_gp
text: data data.table observation data. Column 1: Outcome (Y) Column 2: Exposure treatment (w) Column 3~m: Confounders (C) w vector exposure level compute CERF. GPS_m data.table GPS vectors. Column 1: GPS Column 2: Prediction exposure covariate data sample (e_gps_pred). Column 3: Standard deviation  e_gps (e_gps_std) params list parameters required run process. parameters include: alpha: scaling factor GPS value. beta: scaling factor exposure value. g_sigma: scaling factor kernel function (gamma/sigma). tune_app: tuning approach. Available approaches: : try combinations hyperparameters. alpha, beta, g_sigma can vector parameters. kernel_fn kernel function. default value Gaussian Kernel.

title: Estimate the Conditional Exposure Response Function using Gaussian Process — estimate_cerf_gp
text: cerf_gp object includes following values: TBD

title: Estimate the Conditional Exposure Response Function using Gaussian Process — estimate_cerf_gp

exposure values w.all = seq(0,20,0.1)  data.table::setDT(sim.data)  cerf_gp_obj <- estimate_cerf_gp(sim.data,                                 w.all,                                 GPS_m,                                 params = list(alpha = c(0.1,0.2,0.4),                                               beta=0.2,                                               g_sigma = 1,                                               tune_app = "all")) #> Var1 Var2 Var3  #>  0.1  0.2  1.0  #> Var1 Var2 Var3  #>  0.2  0.2  1.0  #> Var1 Var2 Var3  #>  0.4  0.2  1.0

what: Estimate the Conditional Exposure Response Function using Nearest Neighbor Gaussian Process — estimate_cerf_nngp
title: Estimate the Conditional Exposure Response Function using Nearest Neighbor Gaussian Process — estimate_cerf_nngp
text: Estimates conditional exposure response function (cerf) using nearest neighbor (nn) Gaussian Process (gp). function tune best match (lowest covariate balance) provided set hyperparameters.

title: Estimate the Conditional Exposure Response Function using Nearest Neighbor Gaussian Process — estimate_cerf_nngp
code: estimate_cerf_nngp(data, w, GPS_m, params, kernel_fn)

title: Estimate the Conditional Exposure Response Function using Nearest Neighbor Gaussian Process — estimate_cerf_nngp
text: data data.table observation data. Column 1: Outcome (Y) Column 2: Exposure treatment (w) Column 3~m: Confounders (C) w vector exposure level compute CERF. GPS_m data.table GPS vectors. Column 1: GPS Column 2: Prediction exposure covariate data sample (e_gps_pred). Column 3: Standard deviation  e_gps (e_gps_std) params list parameters required run process. parameters include: alpha: scaling factor GPS value. beta: scaling factor exposure value. g_sigma: scaling factor kernel function (gamma/sigma). tune_app: tuning approach. Available approaches: : try combinations hyperparameters. expand: Scaling factor determine total number nearest neighbors. total 2*expand*n.neighbour. n_neighbor: Number nearest neighbors one side. block_size: Number samples included computation block. Mainly used balance speed memory requirement. Larger block_size faster, requires memory. alpha, beta, g_sigma can vector parameters. kernel_fn kernel function. default value Gaussian Kernel.

code: estimate_mean_sd_nn(   hyperparam,   sigma2,   w_obs,   w,   y_obs,   GPS_m,   n_neighbor = 50,   expand = 2,   block_size = 2000 )

title: Estimate the CERF with the nnGP Model — estimate_mean_sd_nn
text: hyperparam set hyperparameters nnGP. sigma2 scaler representing sigma^2. w_obs vector observed exposure levels. w vector exposure levels CERF estimated. y_obs vector observed outcome values. GPS_m data.table GPS vectors. Column 1: GPS Column 2: Prediction exposure covariate data sample (e_gps_pred). Column 3: Standard deviation  e_gps (e_gps_std) n_neighbor Number nearest neighbours one side (see also expand). expand Scaling factor determine total number nearest neighbours. total 2*expand*n.neighbour. block_size Number samples included computation block. Mainly used balance speed memory requirement. Larger block.size faster, requires memory.

code: set.seed(425) data <- generate_synthetic_data(sample_size = 200, gps_spec = 3)  # Estimate GPS function GPS_m <- train_GPS(cov.mt = as.matrix(data[,-(1:2)]),                    w.all = as.matrix(data$treat)) #> [1]	train-rmse:8.395688  #> [2]	train-rmse:6.617474  #> [3]	train-rmse:5.279930  #> [4]	train-rmse:4.364769  #> [5]	train-rmse:3.744637  #> [6]	train-rmse:3.177252  #> [7]	train-rmse:2.633350  #> [8]	train-rmse:2.383285  #> [9]	train-rmse:2.068275  #> [10]	train-rmse:1.760110  #> [11]	train-rmse:1.591845  #> [12]	train-rmse:1.499740  #> [13]	train-rmse:1.389045  #> [14]	train-rmse:1.269712  #> [15]	train-rmse:1.150313  #> [16]	train-rmse:0.969685  #> [17]	train-rmse:0.916822  #> [18]	train-rmse:0.881205  #> [19]	train-rmse:0.829040  #> [20]	train-rmse:0.773570  #> [21]	train-rmse:0.753146  #> [22]	train-rmse:0.708340  #> [23]	train-rmse:0.627539  #> [24]	train-rmse:0.562319  #> [25]	train-rmse:0.493738  #> [26]	train-rmse:0.443779  #> [27]	train-rmse:0.390704  #> [28]	train-rmse:0.349077  #> [29]	train-rmse:0.318191  #> [30]	train-rmse:0.286245  #> [31]	train-rmse:0.277130  #> [32]	train-rmse:0.245159  #> [33]	train-rmse:0.221798  #> [34]	train-rmse:0.214571  #> [35]	train-rmse:0.207626  #> [36]	train-rmse:0.196346  #> [37]	train-rmse:0.170350  #> [38]	train-rmse:0.160296  #> [39]	train-rmse:0.155315  #> [40]	train-rmse:0.141305  #> [41]	train-rmse:0.134786  #> [42]	train-rmse:0.129128  #> [43]	train-rmse:0.117371  #> [44]	train-rmse:0.112583  #> [45]	train-rmse:0.099892  #> [46]	train-rmse:0.089958  #> [47]	train-rmse:0.083123  #> [48]	train-rmse:0.078359  #> [49]	train-rmse:0.072447  #> [50]	train-rmse:0.067751   # Hyperparameter hyperparam <- c(0.1, 0.2, 1) n_neighbor <- 10 expand <- 1 block_size <- 10000  # Exposure level wi <- 1.2  # Estimate GPS for the exposure level GPS_w = dnorm(wi,               mean = GPS_m$e_gps_pred,               sd = GPS_m$e_gps_std, log = TRUE)  # Order data for easy selection coord_obs = cbind(data$treat, GPS_m$GPS) y_use <- data$Y  obs_ord <- coord_obs[order(coord_obs[,1]),] y_use_ord <- y_use[order(coord_obs[,1])]  noise <- estimate_noise_nn(hyperparam = hyperparam,                            w_obs = data$treat,                            GPS_obs = GPS_m$GPS,                            y_obs = y_use_ord,                            n_neighbor = n_neighbor)

what: Find the Optimal Hyper-parameter for the Nearest Neighbor Gaussian Process — find_optimal_nn
title: Find the Optimal Hyper-parameter for the Nearest Neighbor Gaussian Process — find_optimal_nn
text: Computes covariate balance combincation provided hyper-parameters selects hyper-parameter values minimizes covariate balance.

title: Find the Optimal Hyper-parameter for the Nearest Neighbor Gaussian Process — find_optimal_nn
code: find_optimal_nn(   w_obs,   w,   y_obs,   GPS_m,   design_mt,   hyperparams = expand.grid(seq(0.5, 4.5, 1), seq(0.5, 4.5, 1), seq(0.5, 4.5, 1)),   n_neighbor = 50,   expand = 2,   block_size = 2000 )

title: Find the Optimal Hyper-parameter for the Nearest Neighbor Gaussian Process — find_optimal_nn
text: w_obs vector observed exposure levels. w vector exposure levels CERF estimated. y_obs vector observed outcomes GPS_m data.table GPS vectors. Column 1: GPS Column 2: Prediction exposure covariate data sample (e_gps_pred). Column 3: Standard deviation  e_gps (e_gps_std) design_mt covariate matrix samples (intercept excluded). hyperparams matrix candidate values hyper-parameters, row contains set values hyper-parameters. n_neighbor Number nearest neighbors one side (see also expand). expand Scaling factor determine total number nearest neighbours. total 2*expand*n_neighbor. block_size Number samples included computation block. Mainly used balance speed memory requirement. Larger block_size faster, requires memory.

title: Find the Optimal Hyper-parameter for the Nearest Neighbor Gaussian Process — find_optimal_nn
text: Estimated covariate balance scores grid hyper-parameter values considered hyperparams.
